description: From Middle English whyle, from Old English hwīl, from Proto-West Germanic *hwīlu, from Proto-Germanic *hwīlō (compare Dutch wijl, Low German Wiel, German Weile, Danish hvile (“rest”), Norwegian Bokmål hvile (“rest”)), from Proto-Indo-European *kʷyeh₁- (“to rest”). Cognate with Albanian sillë (“breakfast”), Latin tranquillus, Sanskrit चिर (cirá), Persian شاد‎ (šâd).

definitionGroups.group: An uncertain duration of time, a period of time.

entries.meaning: (US) an uncertain long period of time

examples: I may be conveyed into your chamber; I'll lie under your bed while midnight.

verbs.description: while (third-person singular simple present whiles, present participle whiling, simple past and past participle whiled)

entries.meaning: (transitive, now only in combination with away; see also while away) To pass (time) idly.
examples: I whiled away the hours whilst waiting for him to arrive

entries.meaning: (transitive) To occupy or entertain (someone) in order to let time pass.
Alternative spelling or misspelling of wile.
